data.title: Spring Creek Kayak Tour
data.meta_description: Kayak Tours and Rentals on Spring Creek, Oregon in Klamath County.
data.text:
Embark on an unforgettable adventure for just $89.00 per person. Our tour is designed for up to 16 guests, accompanied by 2 knowledgeable guides. Even with 8 or fewer guests, rest assured that you will have expert guidance from at least 1 guide.

For your safety and convenience, all necessary equipment, including kayaks, paddles, life vests, and whistles, will be provided.

Our licensed Oregon Guides have spent years mastering the art of navigating the waters and are dedicated to ensuring that your experience is nothing short of exceptional.

Special Booking Option:

For groups of 2, we offer the option to reserve a third seat to meet the tour's minimum requirements. Should another group join to meet the minimum requirement, we will refund the third seat. Keep in mind that we do not guarantee a refund for the third seat. Don't miss out on this opportunity - call us to secure your spot using this option.

For groups of 2, we offer an option to reserve a third seat to meet tour minimums. If another group joins to meet the minimum requirement, we will refund the third seat. We do not guarantee a third-seat refund. Please call to book using this option.

For more information contact us at:

E-mail: skylakeswild@gmail.com Phone: 541-891-0435

DAY USE AREA is open year-round

MUSEUM HOURS are 8 am to 8 pm June-August and 8 am to 4 pm September-May.

Collier Memorial State Park features a campground, outdoor museum of historic logging equipment, relocated pioneer village, and a new four-corral, primitive horse camp and trailhead. At the state's finest logging museum, you'll see rare and antique logging equipment dating to the 1880s, as well as more recent pieces.

Railroad buffs will enjoy learning about the role the railroad played in logging. You can imagine the rugged woodsmen and the immense task of moving raw timber with innovation and brute force. The historic cabin village gives you another insight into how these families once lived.

From the equestrian trailhead, you can ride north from the park across national forest land to the Jackson F. Kimball State Recreation Site and beyond.

Whether you come for the day to visit the logging museum, play along Spring Creek, or even camp amongst the pines along the Williamson River - you'll discover a grand adventure at Collier.

Campground info

A Loop

16 full-hookup sites

18 non-hookup sites with water nearby

Hot showers and flush toilets

30 full-hookup sites (nine pull-throughs)

Universal Access

Campsites A30 & A27 are accessible to campers with disabilities.
